moves.1. f4: this move is a tell tale: we are in for some ancient chess theory; this is the Dutch Defense (d4, f5) reversed...
moves.1... d5: so this is the only feasable reply...
moves.2. Nf3: another option is d4, followed by Nc3, and turn this into something very different...
moves.2... g6: like in most Queens' pawn openings, this is always a safe way for Black...
moves.3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 e6 5. d4 Nf6 6. h3 O-O: one of many constellations, this opening can spawn...
moves.7... b6: losing no time: we need to conquer c5 and develop Bc8-Bb7...
moves.8. b3: also for White the way to go: c4 and Bb2...
moves.8... c5 9. dxc5 bxc5 10. Bb2 Bb7: it is clear, that this opening is all about prolonged symmetry: who is the first, to break it up?
moves.11. g4: White cannot play c4 or e4 for now, but that was the way to go: this untangles Blacks' opening...
moves.11... Ne4 12. Bxg7: Ng3 is a threat, so this is forced...
moves.12... Kxg7: now White has to deal with Ng3...
moves.13. Re1: the only safe one: Kg2 is no option after Qc7...
moves.14. c4: probably best: after dxc3 ep, White can just hold this...
moves.17... Qc7: but f4 is forgotten by now...
moves.18... e5: only to make it worse: White has not a single threat...
moves.19. e4: again, Black cannot capture en passant...
moves.20. Qd3: stubborn Queen on the other side: this can lead to no good, against a fierce Queen...
moves.20... Nb4 21. axb4 axb4: this is better than en passant: this opens up lines...
moves.22... Rxa1 23. Rxa1 Nxe4: justice is served: Black wins a pawn back...
moves.25... Bxg2 26. Qxg2: targetting for Ra8, and blocking gxf5...
moves.27. Ra8 Re7: Black is threatening, to push e5-e4...
moves.28. Ne4: mainly making a countermeasure: preparing g4-g5...
moves.28... f6: which is easily solved for now...
moves.29. Ng3: a sound reply: also avoiding e5-e4...
moves.30. Qxb7: of course, Qa2 is no option after Qf3: so this is forced...
moves.33. Kf2 Rc6: Black can only make progress, on the Kings' wing: so we prepare Kh6...
moves.34. Ra7+: White has to react, before Black gets the chance to play h5...
moves.34... Kh6 35. Kg3: the break Black needed: White is getting impatient...
moves.35... Rc8: of course, preparing Rg8+: but White sees a chance...
moves.36. Nxf6 Kg5 37. Nxh7+ Kxf5 38. Rf7+ Ke4: the aftermath is not nice: for White, that is; he is getting in trouble...
moves.39. Ng5+ Kd3 40. Rf3+ Kc2: Black is breaking through the center, with a couple of connected free pawns...
moves.41... Rg8: White needs to get out of this pin desperately...
moves.42. Kg4 e4: also d4-d3 will bring mayhem to White: but this speeds it up...
moves.45. Kf3 Kc3 46. Ne4+ Kd3: not getting any grip on the Black posaition...
moves.47... Rf8+ 48. Rf5: only King moves are  g2 and g4: so this is the last defense...
moves.50... Kd2 51. Nxd4: until the very end: White is a full piece ahead...
moves.51... e1=Q+: also losing the Knight, in all variations: so White resigned...
